(screeching and grunting)

So here we are again, last
time we made this video
I had a little disclaimer in the beginning

and I urged you to keep an
open mind and an open heart.

What we witnessed here on
the banks of Lake Eyasi

with the Hadzabe
hunter-gatherers, challenged me
and no doubt it challenged you.
And I was wondering if we came back,

if we could have a crazier
experience than last time.
It turns out, whew. (laughs)
We definitely could.

And I urge you this time
as well, keep an open mind,
keep an open heart.

These are some of the last
hunter-gatherers on the planet
and they live traditionally.
And I'm just so fortunate
to be able to experience it myself,

and also to share this
experience with you on YouTube.

So, that out of the way,
get ready for a wild ride.

The Hadza people, the last time
we were here, it was crazy.
(panting heavily)
This is exciting.
Go, go, go.
- Ah, oh, ah!

- While we did have a
very successful hunt,
the baboons eluded us.
I was invited back,

this time for a longer
72 hour hunting trek
and deeper into baboon territory.
A larger plan meant a larger group.

Socolo, the tribe's
leader, joined us again,

along with Cha-aba, No-no-no,
Shokula, and Mandola.
They brought some fresh faces,

Tata, Sapo, Godana,
Mayoya, Babua and Tay-Too.
Our local guide, Yusuph, is back too.

He grew up here, and he's
our key to being able
to communicate with the Hadzabe.

And my man, Gumbo, from
Experiential Travel Africa
who organized this trip.

As for me, they call me
Coco, which means friend.
Morning guys.
Ah, ugali.
(group chattering)
Ugali for breakfast.
I'll take some.
(men speaking foreign language)
Ah. (laughs)
Thanks.
It's good.
(speaking foreign language)

No-no-no, it's good to
see you, man. (laughs)
Where's your baboon skin?
(speaking foreign language)
At the other camp.
(men speaking foreign language)
After breakfast, we suit up and get ready.
First though, water.

The group all sit down in the
shade of a giant baobab tree.

It has a hole in it, and
another Hadzabe hunter
casually climbs in.

I peer up inside the
baobab, to see wooden steps
have been hammered inside.
Then I get stung.
Just wondering what it was.
I just got stung by a bee.

I don't think I've ever
seen anybody climb a tree
from the inside before.
(laughing)
This is crazy.

So let me ask you, which
are you scared of most,

heights, confined
spaces, stinging insects?
Because this has all three.

(man yelping)
Is that him getting stung?
Is that him getting stung by bees?

- Yes.
- Yeah, it is?
(all laughing)
- Oh, look at the bees.
(bees buzzing)
(man speaking foreign language)
It's like a coffin full of bees.
Yeah, but no thanks.
(man speaking foreign language)
Wow.
(boy speaking foreign language)
Man.
(speaking foreign language)
Look at him.
(Mike laughing)
Let me take this back.
(Mike laughing)
Oh my God.

I still don't quite understand,
and maybe I never will,

the unspoken agreement the
Hadzabe have with bees.
Maybe some ancestral pact with nature,

or maybe they just don't
give a fit about being stung.
Good, yeah?
(speaking foreign language)

Look at that, look at
the color of that honey,

it is like the deepest
golden yellow I've seen
in my entire life.
It's like Topaz.
Ooh!
It's good, man.

Mm-hmm

Mm-hmm
- Mm-hmm.

- There is nothing else like
this honey in the planet.
I can put this into an IV and mainline it.
It so good, I'm eating the wax.
(laughing)
It's that good. It's that good.

It's worth getting stung
on the tongue for it.
It's that good.
Our honey tree climber's name is Halua.
Remember this face, we'll see him again

and he'll play a reoccurring
role in this wild adventure.

Right after, we find something,
it begins with a screech.
(dog yelping)
(bushes rustling)
It's a family of mongeese, mongooses,
or whatever they're called.
(speaking foreign language)
They go on our pockets for later,
As we're sprinting through the bush,
trying to catch animals,

weaving in and out of each
other and dogs and everything,

the poison arrows are
like stuck in my mind,

that one little nick on any
of those that they're holding

is like the magic wand of
death, my heart will stop.

So I'm trying to keep
a little bit of space,

but they're being really
careful with them,

which is probably a good thing
because they'll kill you,
that's the whole point.
(speaking foreign language)
(growling)
(leaves rustling)
(upbeat music)

Every 20 minutes or so,
we stop and we listen.
(upbeat music)

Socolo finds the fresh
dung of a large antelope
called an eland.
It's close.
(leaves rustling)

This is the most dangerous thing
in the woods, these things.
- [Yusuph] Yeah, that's the track.
- It's this way, all right, all right.
It came this way.
(leaves rustling)
Oh, I'm getting excited.
My shirt is getting destroyed.
(laughing)
Worth it though.
Worth it though.

We're gonna have some new
scars for sure, but...
Scars are always good stories, right?
(men yelling)
It's huge.
It sees us though, it's starting to run.
And it's on the other side of the ravine.
So, uh, these jungle thorns!
Oh my God.
I feel so awkward and slow.
(men shouting)
Oh, there it is.
Yeah, I can see it.
Yeah, I can see it.
(men shouting)
Wrecked.
Wrecked, wrecked, wrecked.
We didn't get it though.
I don't think we got it.
Half the crew is still chasing.
But it's swinging a miss.
It's about a lot of hard work.

In the craziness, we all
got separated, so we chill.

While we wait for the
group, Tata hammers a rock
on a large piece of wood.

The bark will be stripped
and these will eventually
be carved into bows.
(Yusuph laughing)
What's going on?
- What's happened to your T-shirt?
- [Gumbo] This is part of the job, right?
- I know, right?
Oh my God, half my shirt's gone.
(laughing)
Up on the side, Mandola, Tata and Tay-Too,

have concocted a new plan to
attack the baboons at night.
They explain.
(speaking foreign language)
Now, I don't speak Hadzane,
but I think I get what they're saying.
"Hey Mike, when we go, zip it."
Message received.
Okay, and what do we do until then, chill?

- Now?
- Yeah.
- Now it's chilling.
- So the plan for now then is to chill,
and that's something I'm really good at.
So, see you in a bit.

We missed the eland, but
with wood, honey and mongoose
in our pockets, we tracked back to camp.

On the way we encounter a
member of the Datooga tribe,
grazing his cattle.
This is what Socolo speaks about
during my interview with him later,

it's one of the biggest
threats to the Hadzabe,

their land is being
encroached on from all sides
by other tribes who graze animals,
making all the wild ones flee.
At breakfast, they had been eating ugali

because it's getting
increasingly harder to hunt food.

There are 1,500 Hadza
people left on the planet,

many of which have had to abandon
their typical way of life.
They've had to modernize.

In my eyes, this is the
real world, this is us.
I know some of you don't think so,
I know some of you judge,

but honestly, is this modernization
for better or for worse?
Is it right or is it wrong?

Some could argue that
even making this video
destroys their culture.

Others could argue that
these videos could save it,

to bring awareness to something
that's slowly disappearing.

But I don't know the answer,
maybe one of you does.

We speak about endangered
animals all the time,
but rarely endangered people.
There are cultural extinctions too.
Languages, practices, rituals,
those can all go away forever as well.
All I know is that if this all goes away,
so will some of the magic in this world.
(soaring music)

Once back at the camp, I do
that interview I spoke about.

That video has been posted,
but I'll give you a teaser,

I asked Socolo what's the
most important thing in life.
(speaking foreign language)
(Yusuph laughing)

I think I know what the
most important thing
in his life is, because he's like,
"Oh my God, the baboons are coming close.
They're right over there."

All right.
(speaking foreign language)
First though, we had dinner to make.
Remember our agreement in the beginning?
Keep an open mind, right?
All right, I'm here with Socolo,
he's got the mongoose in his hand,
he just handed me a piece,
(Socolo speaking foreign language)
(Mike laughing)
And he also gave me some ugali.
And it's like corn flour.

Thing is part of me is like,
do I really wanna eat this?

And part of me is like,
hell yeah, you gotta eat it.

You're in the middle of
nowhere with a tribe,

you've come to party with them,
you come to hunt with them,

you gotta eat the gifts,
you gotta eat the offerings.
So here we are, mongoose down the hatch.
Kinda chewy, kinda bony.

You think like, meat's not
like ice cream flavors,

everyone just doesn't really
have a different taste.
This just tastes like meat, basically.

It's a little bit chewier,
a little bit gamier
than I normally like it,

but honestly, after
hiking 17 kilometers today

through thorns and rocks,
this tastes pretty damn good.
So I might go back for seconds.
(men speaking foreign language)
- What are they saying, Gumbo?

- Hm?
- What are they saying?

- Well, actually it's evening
now, so they're kind of trying
to plan for the attack of the baboon.
So they normally don't go with dogs
and they will need a few people

and they are going to
have stealth movement.
So they don't need noise,

and actually they don't
need people who got fear.

So only warriors from the
remaining group there should go.

So they're kind of selecting
people who would be going.

- I however, was not
selected as a warrior.

So, let me get this straight,
they were saying I couldn't go
because they are going with no light?
- Yes, it's a big point.
- And also no shoes?

- Uh, shoes you can have,
but you have to walk gently.

- Gently, but they're
taking their shoes off
because of the sound?

- Yeah.
- Okay.
- They're scared about the sound.

- I mean, obviously I'm already
filled with puncture wounds

from the thorns today, my
shirt's have torn off my body,
do you think we could-

- The question is, can
you walk without light?
- I will try.

And if it's too much,
then I'll turn around.
But I would love to try if it's possible.
And if I have to take off my shoes,

dude, I've been training my
entire life for this moment.
(both laughing)

I haven't worn shoes since
I was like six years old.
I love going barefoot.

So if there was one moment to
test my ultimate hobbit feet,
this is the moment.
I promise, I won't scare the baboons away.
(laughing)
I'll try, then I'd love to join.
- Okay, that's good.
- Okay. Can we ask?
- Socolo.
- They said, yes.

So, with a belly full of
mongoose and killer bee honey,
I set off with the Hadzabe tribe
to raid a baboon camp at night.
Wish me luck.

- Good luck, man.
- Thank you, thank you.

- I'm coming with you.
- Are you coming too?

- Yeah, yeah.
- Okay.

What Yusuph explains is
that there'll be two groups.

Both will sneak up, one
will make a distraction

while the other attacks
from the other side.
Along the way, we find a fire.
It's Halua, he wants to join,
and he's got some ammunition for us too.
(men speaking foreign language)

I walk in the darkness with the
pit of my elbow over my face
to not get thorns in my eyes.

My other hand pats around
like the feelers of an insect.
About 20 minutes later, we hear demons.

They will throw the stones

can shoot them from the top.

I had never seen baboons up close before.

While returning, we passed the point

We tell the others, we saw

Cha-aba!

It was unbelievable, man, from just there.
This is crazy.

I decide to join the guys
for a night by the fire.
Oh yeah, thanks man.

Just watch out for those

It should be a good night's sleep.

What's that quote?
You don't tell stories about the nights

Yeah, it was one of those nights.

The next morning we head out

The dogs come with us

Together with noses and
eyes, we search for clues.
Is this blood?

- So that's from last night?
Watch my step here.

So we found the arrow

- Eh.

We're all a bit stumped.

We chase.

It sounds like they got one, yeah?
Oh man.

joining the guys one

they slice it's back-end.

- They like to eat-

Some of the dogs have serious injuries
in the war with baboons.

Halua, the honey climber,
finds a snail shell
and relieves himself inside of it.

Then he pours the contents
into the wounds of the dogs
as a natural antiseptic.
All in all, two baboons were caught.

All that hard work will be
enough food for a couple of days.
So we head back to camp for a feast.

but YouTube can't handle it,
I've learned the hard way.

But also there's another meaning,

and they will know how

And also it's their way to become a chief,
if we kill a lot of animals
so they choose you to be a chief.

- It's beginning to rain a little bit.

It's just the skin left, which

There's something called

you gotta eat the turkey

And so I never really
refuse an invitation.

If I was offered baboon,
